The following telegraph has been received by the Minister of Agriculture:
"From Sir Charles Tupper:
The English authorities declared that the Canadian cattle imported in the Oregon and Nipissing districts were not fit for market. I went to Liverpool on Monday and succeeded in demonstrating that the cattle were free from any disease. I returned last night. This morning, and this morning, the Secretary of State for Post Office announced that orders will be given immediately for the release of all Canadian cattle." This will be good news for Canadians.
THE NORTH WEST COUNCIL

THURSDAY, SEPT. 13.

The Lieutenant Governor took the chair at 2 o'clock.

THE MUNICIPAL BILL.

The bill was taken up and on this and succeeding days all proper proceedings, the Council proceeded every day until Monday at nine o'clock a.m. The bill virtually passed yesterday and now is ready for the assent of His Excellency. Moose Jaw, Regina, Qu'Appelle and other places can have an opportunity of adequate incorporation.

FRIDAY, SEPT. 14.

Mr. Oliver brought in a bill on this subject.

SATURDAY, SEPT. 15.

His Honor took the chair at 10 o'clock and the Municipal Bill was proceeded with.

SUNDAY, SEPT. 16.

The Governor took the chair at 9 a.m., the bill dealing with Municipalities occupied the whole day.

On Tuesday the Committee from the Civic Committee met on the Council and made suggestions to the effect that one month's residence and fees or taxes, be the test of qualification of electors, and that the qualifications of mayor aldermen or councillors should be the same as those who are entitled to the right of their division freeholders to the amount of $500, or tenants $1,000 or a certain proportion thereof, so that the qualifications of electors should be freeholders in their own right or right of their wives or husbands, and that before the time by law, have to run, the number of aldermen or councillors in each ward shall be fixed, and that the number of wards (whether as one or more) should be optional.

WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 19.

Mr. Jackson moved that the Council be adjourned to the Government building praying for a recess of grievances, which was ordered to meet for consideration.

The Municipal Bill passed through committee on the Council returning.

Mr. White gave notice that he would move that the bill be referred to the Standing Committee.

During the week Bills on woods, contracts, protection of sheep, auction laws, banking house, police force, local law and justiciable were before the stage.

The Council adjourned at 10 o'clock and 7 p.m., when they again took up the Municipal Bill and adopted some of the suggestions made by the Civic Committee.

PROSPECTUS OF THE Prince Albert Directory AND BUSINESS GUIDE.

It is proposed to issue a Business Directory for the town of Prince Albert and District, containing a list of all persons engaged in business, who will publish the advertisements of such persons as may desire to be included therein, at a reasonable rate and a short period.

This edition will contain a history of Prince Albert, its present condition and future prospects, together with a list of the year's crops, as far as they are known, and a list of the principal firms, excepting those engaged in agriculture, and a description of the town and its surroundings.

A large number of firms will be paid.

Brantford, Ontario, has been engaged recently, which will be distributed throughout the Province and the Western Country.

It is believed that by this means, benefit will result, not only to each individual advertiser, but also to the town itself, whose prosperity will become better known and more widely appreciated, and a large number of inquiries encouraged to this end.

Competition of the Beauties.

London has a lovely competition among its beauties, particularly in the case of the women who took the greatest advantage of the occasion. Miss Langley won of the best, and Miss Langley was awarded by Lady Dudley. The prize was presented by Lady Dudley and Lady Langley was awarded the prize. Miss Langley and Miss Dudley were the only two who took part in the competition. Miss Langley was the first to arrive, followed by Miss Dudley.

The above will be disposed of at reasonable prices and on easy terms of payment. Full information regarding these lands will be given at the offices of the Company in Winnipeg and Montreal.

C. J. BRYCE, Land Commissioner.
MOUNTED POLICE.

The Mounted Police Force is not yet officially organized, but members of it have been recently appointed by the Government. The force will be under the command of Mr. Macdonald, who has been appointed to the position. It is expected that the force will be ready for service in a few weeks.

COMMUNICATIONS.

AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.

To the Editor of The Times:

In your issue of last week you mentioned the formation of an agricultural society in the townships of the surrounding country. A society of that kind is of great importance to the farmers, and will promote the welfare of the community. It is proposed to hold meetings at least once a month, and to exchange ideas and experiences among the members.
